history.content:
One question to ask yourself might be, why did you do poorly in 61C?

Was the material confusing? Did you have too many other commitments and didn't work enough? Something else?

Having received a poor grade in 61C does not, a priori, imply you'll do poorly in upper divisions. But the answer to the big question I ask, allows you to understand what will cause you issues.

children.subject:
I would say don't worry about CS 168. There's very little in that class that draws on CS 61C material.

For CS 161 you'll need to be a little careful since the class expects knowledge about calling conventions and stack layout for one module of the class. But CS 161 does a tutorial on this anyway so you'll have a chance to get refreshed/caught up. Plus, CS 161 uses x86, so it doesn't draw directly on CS 61C. Everyone, including those who did well in CS 61C, will have to pick this up.

CS 162 is a little more problematic. It draws heavily on concepts from CS 61C, most notably C programming, memory layout, caches, virtual memory, and to a small extent even ISA/processor design (regarding how interrupts are designed/implemented). That said, I agree with the above answer that doing poorly in CS 61C doesn't necessarily imply you'll do poorly in this class. You should try to understand why you did poorly in CS 61C. If you really feel comfortable with the material and enjoyed it, you'll probably be fine.

history.content:
Hello, I got a passing (but not so great) grade at 61C. C+ to be precise. Would this affect my performance in upper division classes such as 161/162/168? I really would like to take all of those because they all sound super interesting, but I thought 61C was super difficult.

For more information, I did pretty well in 61B on the other hand, and I think I have a super solid foundation on data structures and am pretty psyched for 170. 

Edit: Reason I did badly in 61C because I was taking two other techs. Would not recommend. (16B was pretty heavy, and 188 not so heavy but still a CS class)
history.subject: Did badly in 61C
